commits.message:
Merge pull request #189 from lanwen/checkstyle

dummy checkstyle fix for trailing whitespaces
ignore cache tests on windows
fix flaky test for webhook without sign
dummy checkstyle fix for trailing whitespaces
Update RequirePostWithGHHookPayload.java

Merge pull request #172 from stephenc/jenkins-45448

[FIXED JENKINS-45448] Add a display name to GitHub Servers configuration

[JENKINS-48012] Require a X-Hub-Signature header when receiving a hook payload and if… (#188)

* Require a X-Hub-Signature header when receiving a hook payload and if a secret is configured

* Make it clear that the hook signature is only validated if a hook secret is specified in the GitHub plugin config

pull_requests.title: Always update existing hooks to make sure all options (e.g. shared se…
pull_requests.body: …cret) are up-to-date Easy option for solving https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-48610. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/185)

commits.message: Restore source compatibility of GitHub plugin after #183 (#186)

pull_requests.title: Update Parent POM to 2.37 and use Apache HttpComponents API 4.x plugin
pull_requests.body: I was running PCT against the plugin and hit some issues with that. - [x] - Update Parent POM and resolve upper bound dependency issues - [x] - Switch to https://github.com/jenkinsci/apache-httpcomponents-client-4-api-plugin so that GitHubWebHookFullTest does not blow up with `ON: NoClassDefFoundError: Could not initialize class com.jayway.restassured.RestAssured` due to the missing httpmime dependency @reviewbybees @lanwen @KostyaSha @raul-arabaolaza --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/187)

commit_comments.body:
I know :)
Unfortunately, our release process and under-resourcing block the frequent updates. 
IF there're known issues, let's go forward with 1.532

review_comments.body: getLastBuiltRevision() and getSha1() are nullable. It is preferable to check them to avoid crashes like JENKINS-23641 ( #46 )
Move to messages?

commits.message:
[JENKINS-47820] Update github-api dependency (#183)

Updating org.jenkins-ci.plugins.github-api to the newest version should resolve an issue JENKINS-47820 about parsing large IDs from github.

Cleanup help text blocks (#178)

There are a few gramatical errors in the help text associated with the plugin. I am not an English major, so there may still be issues. I do think this improves it a bit.
[JENKINS-43786] Adapted the administrative monitor to the new UI definition (#177)

pull_requests.title: [JENKINS-43786] More compatible adaptation
pull_requests.body: [JENKINS-43786](https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-43786) Downstream of https://github.com/jenkinsci/jenkins/pull/2857 @KostyaSha, @lanwen, What do you think? --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/179)

commits.message: Only `jenkins-core` and `structs` may depend on `symbol-annotation`. All other plugins must depend on `structs`. (#176)

commit_comments.body: People are asking for this in [JENKINS-15045](https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-15045), any status?

So… what to do when someone else had this plugin configured and apparently working with an API token, and now I update the plugin and _Discard old data_ and there is just a blank OAuth token field? And should this not be integrated with the Credentials plugin?
OK, sounds like the configuration of the old plugin was not actually working. Should what you just said be written up on the plugin wiki?

review_comments.body: case: `GitHub`
Consider `Computer.threadPoolForRemoting`, to avoid using extra threads just for this plugin.

It is certainly possible your observed occurrence of JENKINS-14362 is related to the change of the thread pool but it does not seem likely to me, especially as you appear to have changed other major parts of your environment at the same time.

Does `newInstance` need to be overridden at all, given that the default implementation would I think do just what you wrote here?

Also, does your change preserve the behavior of treating the property as absent in case the `projectUrl` was omitted? Or was that behavior undesirable to begin with and it is OK to drop it?

commits.message: Use https example url in help string (#175)

[JENKINS-45448] Reduce the likelyhood of a core dump due to groovy dependency conflict

See https://github.com/jenkinsci/github-plugin/commit/5dfb7804f9b10b9cf23d036cf3b61c5aeb8f4aa2 for precedent

[JENKINS-45448] OK, need to bump to git 3.4.0 to pick up dependency fixes for tests

- Likely could get away with slightly older, but needs to be newer than 2.4.0
[JENKINS-45448] Checkstyle doesn't like name shadowing or underscores
Add CI service from ci.jenkins.io (#174)
[JENKINS-45448] Pick up release of scm-api
[JENKINS-45448] Clarify public github constant
[JENKINS-45448] Avoid one letter var names

[JENKINS-45448] Make getName() a simple getter

- Moves logic to getDisplayName
[JENKINS-45448] Add getDisplayName to return the formatted display name
[FIXED JENKINS-45448] Add a display name to GitHub Servers configuration

pull_requests.title: WIP [JENKINS-33228] Consolidation of the GitHub Server list
pull_requests.body: Todo - [ ] Refactor credentials usage to use authentication tokens - [ ] Migrate existing credentials to GitHub OAuth credential type - [ ] Change server configuration to enable extension by other plugins that need to record information --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/181)

commits.message: jenkinsci/jenkins is deprecated (#173)

commit_comments.body:
Got some issues with git and maven release plugin in pre-1.532
hey, 1.532 is already 1 year old !

pull_requests.title: Add push event information as arguments to triggered jobs.
pull_requests.body: This change adds the git reference and head commit as arguments to triggered jobs. This allows Jenkins jobs to implement specialized logic. For example, a job can now have different behavior if the develop branch is pushed to vs. master. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/169)

pull_requests.title: WIP Deprecate magic method.
pull_requests.body: Relying on this manageHooks may end to situation that it will try register hook for GH server that has disabled hooks. PS One line fluent is hardly readable for eyes. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/149)

commit_comments.body: You known/handle this exception. Why throw IOException instead AbortException + error.getMessage() ?
Very not obvious description, Result is usually a build object option. Call it like "Mark build result on status failure as"
Using advanced button for only ONE available option  at all in this publisher looks crazy.

pull_requests.title: Support aborted build status reporting
pull_requests.body: This pull request supports reporting aborted builds to Github as errors. Currently, aborted builds use the default status which is pending. This can be confusing for automated tools. This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/133)

pull_requests.title: Ignorable pusher
pull_requests.body: This defines a regular expression to which the name or email of an ignorable pusher is to be matched. Such a push will be ignored. Normally a preceding push of Jenkins him self could be prevented that way. [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/58)

pull_requests.title: Add ability to specify GitHub events.
pull_requests.body: Adds functionality to support other GitHub event types other than push. Extension of https://github.com/jenkinsci/github-plugin/pull/53. [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/54)

issue_comments.body: Committed in d8da3ab2157c6361d63ea2a5b0b98019fb6b76e7
Can you update the commit in the pull request to not change the imports?

review_comments.body: Is this change required to fix the URLs?
Could the repoName and ownerName still be used from the repository JSON object? And just the host parsed from the url field?
I personally put it in my `~/.m2/settings.xml` file so that any jenkins plugin being built has access to it
This [blog post](http://www.sonatype.com/people/2009/02/why-putting-repositories-in-your-poms-is-a-bad-idea/) is worth reading on this subject.

issue_comments.body: updated. sorry :)
Our apologies for the delay in integrating this. It's now a part of the repository towrad 0.7
Sorry for the delay in integrating this change. I've squashed your changes in one and integrated toward version 0.7
Thanks. Merged with 1.16 dependency to github-api.
Looks like this fix has effectively been already integrated when Kevin added GitHub:fi support. Closing.

It appears to me that there's a consensus to merge it, so I just went ahead and merged it in.

If any additional formatting changes are needed (not that I'm saying they are needed), it can be made after the merge.
This pull request cannot be automatically merged. Can you please clean it up and re-open? Thanks!

Hm, looks like this is still using "commit" (singular):

https://github.com/jenkinsci/github-plugin/commit/7e2a37f829cff1b21cb309423198297bb5cb6c98

shows the actual commit, 

https://github.com/jenkinsci/github-plugin/commits/7e2a37f829cff1b21cb309423198297bb5cb6c98

shows the commit list.

Doh, you're right. I'm moving my repo from an ssh server to github, and this commit didn't exist yet on github. In my infinite wisdom, I added an 's' to 'commit' and it 'worked', but I didn't look close enough to notice that the commit wasn't on that list.

I'm closing this ticket down. Thanks for playing :)
@stigkj thanks for the feedback... changes committed. I blame intellij :) well at least for the formatting....

issue_comments.body: Good god, please fix that formatting!
wow. impressive autonotification
Will update tests and verify operation.
Patched to use "if" statement to massage incoming url, rather than figuring out universal regexes.
FYI.... you don't have to close the pull request, just push your changes to the same branch and buildhive will do another run on it.

commit_comments.body: @nukulb are going to fix/revert this soon? GitHub enterprise users are screwed now and can't use the github-service anymore.
@nukulb - sure, I'll do a test tomorrow when I'm back at work

@nukulb - I tested with GH Enterprise 11.10.341, all fine - can you do a release of it?
If you'r short in time, just let me know and I'll do it...
Content-type is called 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' in the github UI

be careful, the event header might have a value like "push" or "pull", but the content-type is responsible to whether the content my be encoded or not. In the case of the service hook, the user has no chance to change the content-type so, it will be `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`. But in the case of a WebHook, the default value is  `application/json`.
The best in this situation would probably be to implement this the same way as in the Bitbucket Plugin: https://github.com/jenkinsci/bitbucket-plugin/blob/master/src/main/java/com/cloudbees/jenkins/plugins/BitbucketHookReceiver.java#L53-L56
...but `application/vnd.github+form`is just wrong.

In terms of the `X-Github-Event`: I have talked to the GitHub Support and after the confusion with this fix - they might not include the header into the enterprise version.
The ".git" part should be optional, and the dot should get escaped; the ?: makes it a non-capturing group: (?:.git)?

passing the api token here appears to be incorrect.  The connectToEnterprise method is expecting a password and not a token.  The end result being that to connect to a Github enterprise instance you have to place your password as cleartext in the token field when configuring jenkins for the plugin to work correctly.  I have verified this behavior using the latest jenkins, github plugin, and github api versions.

Mark Klunder

So that explains why I got this message from Jenkins...I guess I'll click the "Discard Unreadable Data" button and see what happens...

Unreadable Data

It is acceptable to leave unreadable data in these files, as Jenkins will safely ignore it. To avoid the log messages at Jenkins startup you can permanently delete the unreadable data by resaving these files using the button below.

Type
com.cloudbees.jenkins.GitHubPushTrigger$DescriptorImpl  

Name
Build when a change is pushed to GitHub 

Error
MissingFieldException: No field 'apiToken' found in class 'com.cloudbees.jenkins.Credential'
Yep. The API token was a relic from API v1 and v2. It was completely deprecated back in March of 2012. This change updates the plugin to be compatible with API v3 using OAuth tokens.

Based on my understanding the old API tokens only worked with APIv2, which was officially shutdown over a year ago. There's no way to get an API token like that any longer. To get an equivalent OAuth token, a user just has to go to https://github.com/settings/applications and create a Personal Access Token (or generate a more narrowly scoped token via the Authorizations API (http://developer.github.com/v3/oauth/#oauth-authorizations-api).

review_comments.body: Thanks for the review! I'm pretty swamped with work at the moment, but will take a look once I'm able to surface for some air.

commit_comments.body:
FYI:  this commit caused https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-23661 and https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-23662

Fixed by https://github.com/github/github-services/commit/19a3c876e483e2470f21f756ac9ee0499b5c4322
I commented on your fix. Just trying to understand what happened here.

I will fix or revert it today.

On Mon, Jul 14, 2014 at 2:32 AM, Dominik Bartholdi <notifications@github.com

> wrote:
> 
> @nukulb https://github.com/nukulb are going to fix/revert this soon?
> GitHub enterprise users are screwed now and can't use the github-service
> anymore.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/jenkinsci/github-plugin/commit/bcc3bc1ca704b2be3f1475b616fa1b209986a1fd#commitcomment-6991178
> .
## 

_Nukul Bhasin_

@imod I just merged the pull request for the fix but since github already fixed the issue and I don't have access to github enterprise I cannot do an end to end test. Would you mind testing it? If you need help building it etc.. I can help.
@imod can you release it please, I don't seem to getting any time to get back to this.

@imod thanks I can have a deeper look at the implementation from BitbucketHookReceiver.

The event header value can be "push", "pull_request" and many others. Most of these events below generated their "X-Github-Event" type. This plugin only supports the payload for "push", so if you pass the payload for "pull_request" into processGithubPayload, it will throw exceptions and its not clear why it breaks. That was whole point of adding this change.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/701733/3656576/0262d898-1188-11e4-94e2-3d49a369d997.png)

The json structure for the payload is different for each of eventTypes. As far as content-type is concerned. The webhook UI from github actually allows you to choose it

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/701733/3656658/06339de4-1189-11e4-98c9-744c74322118.png)

For the actual language of the error message, this commit doesn't actually change the error message when no payload is specified.

```
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Not intended to be browsed interactively (must specify payload parameter). " Make sure payload version is 'application/vnd.github+form'.");
```

We should definitely fix the above error message as well as its obviously just wrong.

The only thing this commit adds is if the event is not of "push" type it won't call processGithubPayload and instead it throws an exception, which is lot better than calling the method and having that throw exceptions that are hard to read.
`application/x-www-form-urlencoded` is what github sends, making this a very misleading error message.

review_comments.body: It wasn't although it was required in order to get the project to build.  Is this suppose to be configured elsewhere on my local machine?
Yes, that could be a little bit more stable.
Being a person that has never used maven or build a jenkins plugin this took a little while to figure out, is there a reason it shouldn't be in the pom?

This is not correct.  There is a distinct difference between `git@github.com:jenkinsci/jenkins.git` and `ssh://git@github.com/jenkinsci/jenkins.git`.  It might look like they are interchangeable to you, but that is incorrect.  In fact, by default, the second one would be identical to: `ssh://git@github.com:22/jenkinsci/jenkins.git`.  Note that the SSH port number must be specified via a colon.  With your change, you are now assuming that the path to the git repository is "22/jenkinsci/jenkins.git", and that is wrong.

Take Gerrit code review, as an example:  `ssh://jenkins@gerrit.company.com:29418/jenkinsci/jenkins.git`.  This is the proper format of an `ssh://` URL.  Your change makes that incompatible.
Yep, you're correct. I wasn't paying attention closely enough.
`cause` is not used
Thanks for the comment!  I've made the change locally and am testing in our build environment.  I'll update this pull-request shortly.

Interestingly enough, I've been seeing some threads lock up the CPUs since making this change.  The stacktraces i see in the monitor are identical to those in the bug @ https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-14362.

If it's not caught soon enough, the memory get's sucked up and swapping starts to occur.  When i manually kill the threads, the resources are released.

Although i did only upgrade from 1.515 to 1.516, I think you are correct in saying it's not likely related.  I read some of the other comments in the bug and realized that some links i was sending out in emails used the ConsoleFull instead of Console.  Since changing that, i have not seen the exception, but i'll keep my eyes on it.

When i have more time, likely after tomorrow, i'll see if i can change it back in order to reproduce the problem.  If reproducible, i'll attempt to install your jenkins build w/ the proposed fix.
Should probably be `GitHub.connectToEnterprise(apiUrl,oauthAccessToken)` to match `login()`
I can confirm that it should be GitHub.connectToEnterprise(apiUrl,oauthAccessToken) I made that change locally and saw everything with my github enterprise start working
Why not make this `Pattern.compile("git@(.+):([^/]+)/([^/]+)(?:\\.git)")` and avoid the need for a second set of patterns?
I attempted to do that in every way that I could come up with and none of them succeeded in matching all the required input formats. If you can make it work that would certainly be an improvement.

> Also, does your change preserve the behavior of treating the property as absent in case the 
> projectUrl was omitted? Or was that behavior undesirable to begin with and it is OK to drop it?

No, problem, It works for me. But it creates unnecessary GithubProjectProperty instance.
I'll close this pull request and create new one, which checks whether tpp is null or not null.

Having a look at this PR to see if it could help with a problem we're having.

Are you sure that `ref` always points to `ref/heads/`? AFAIK if you push tags to GitHub then `ref` could refer to `refs/tags/`. An actual event we see can look like:

``` json
{
  "ref": "refs/tags/[TAG]",
  "after": "[SAH1]",
  "before": "0000000000000000000000000000000000000000",
  "created": true,
  "deleted": false,
  "forced": true,
  "compare": "https://github.com/[ORG]/[REPO]/compare/[TAG]",
  "commits": [],
 ...
```

Or am I misunderstanding where `ref` comes from?

I think we do want tags - I can see cases were it is useful anyway.

I'm making the required change now.

Looking at this further, it looks like we don't need to deal with tags specifically, because the sha1 matches the tag. Instead we should restrict the branches to ref/heads. This PR looks like it would do bad things with anything that didnt match ref/heads.

commit_comments.body: You known/handle this exception. Why throw IOException instead AbortException + error.getMessage() ?

pull_requests.title: Support aborted build status reporting
pull_requests.body: This pull request supports reporting aborted builds to Github as errors. Currently, aborted builds use the default status which is pending. This can be confusing for automated tools. This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/133)

pull_requests.title: Ignorable pusher
pull_requests.body: This defines a regular expression to which the name or email of an ignorable pusher is to be matched. Such a push will be ignored. Normally a preceding push of Jenkins him self could be prevented that way. [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/58)

pull_requests.title: Add ability to specify GitHub events.
pull_requests.body: Adds functionality to support other GitHub event types other than push. Extension of https://github.com/jenkinsci/github-plugin/pull/53. [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/jenkinsci/github-plugin/54)

commit_comments.body: @nukulb are going to fix/revert this soon? GitHub enterprise users are screwed now and can't use the github-service anymore.
@nukulb - sure, I'll do a test tomorrow when I'm back at work

@nukulb - I tested with GH Enterprise 11.10.341, all fine - can you do a release of it?
If you'r short in time, just let me know and I'll do it...
Content-type is called 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' in the github UI

be careful, the event header might have a value like "push" or "pull", but the content-type is responsible to whether the content my be encoded or not. In the case of the service hook, the user has no chance to change the content-type so, it will be `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`. But in the case of a WebHook, the default value is  `application/json`.
The best in this situation would probably be to implement this the same way as in the Bitbucket Plugin: https://github.com/jenkinsci/bitbucket-plugin/blob/master/src/main/java/com/cloudbees/jenkins/plugins/BitbucketHookReceiver.java#L53-L56
...but `application/vnd.github+form`is just wrong.

In terms of the `X-Github-Event`: I have talked to the GitHub Support and after the confusion with this fix - they might not include the header into the enterprise version.
The ".git" part should be optional, and the dot should get escaped; the ?: makes it a non-capturing group: (?:.git)?

passing the api token here appears to be incorrect.  The connectToEnterprise method is expecting a password and not a token.  The end result being that to connect to a Github enterprise instance you have to place your password as cleartext in the token field when configuring jenkins for the plugin to work correctly.  I have verified this behavior using the latest jenkins, github plugin, and github api versions.

Mark Klunder

So that explains why I got this message from Jenkins...I guess I'll click the "Discard Unreadable Data" button and see what happens...

Unreadable Data

It is acceptable to leave unreadable data in these files, as Jenkins will safely ignore it. To avoid the log messages at Jenkins startup you can permanently delete the unreadable data by resaving these files using the button below.

Type
com.cloudbees.jenkins.GitHubPushTrigger$DescriptorImpl  

Name
Build when a change is pushed to GitHub 

Error
MissingFieldException: No field 'apiToken' found in class 'com.cloudbees.jenkins.Credential'
Yep. The API token was a relic from API v1 and v2. It was completely deprecated back in March of 2012. This change updates the plugin to be compatible with API v3 using OAuth tokens.

Based on my understanding the old API tokens only worked with APIv2, which was officially shutdown over a year ago. There's no way to get an API token like that any longer. To get an equivalent OAuth token, a user just has to go to https://github.com/settings/applications and create a Personal Access Token (or generate a more narrowly scoped token via the Authorizations API (http://developer.github.com/v3/oauth/#oauth-authorizations-api).

> wrote:

## 

_Nukul Bhasin_

@imod I just merged the pull request for the fix but since github already fixed the issue and I don't have access to github enterprise I cannot do an end to end test. Would you mind testing it? If you need help building it etc.. I can help.
@imod can you release it please, I don't seem to getting any time to get back to this.

@imod thanks I can have a deeper look at the implementation from BitbucketHookReceiver.

The event header value can be "push", "pull_request" and many others. Most of these events below generated their "X-Github-Event" type. This plugin only supports the payload for "push", so if you pass the payload for "pull_request" into processGithubPayload, it will throw exceptions and its not clear why it breaks. That was whole point of adding this change.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/701733/3656576/0262d898-1188-11e4-94e2-3d49a369d997.png)

The json structure for the payload is different for each of eventTypes. As far as content-type is concerned. The webhook UI from github actually allows you to choose it

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/701733/3656658/06339de4-1189-11e4-98c9-744c74322118.png)

For the actual language of the error message, this commit doesn't actually change the error message when no payload is specified.

```
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Not intended to be browsed interactively (must specify payload parameter). " Make sure payload version is 'application/vnd.github+form'.");
```

We should definitely fix the above error message as well as its obviously just wrong.

The only thing this commit adds is if the event is not of "push" type it won't call processGithubPayload and instead it throws an exception, which is lot better than calling the method and having that throw exceptions that are hard to read.
`application/x-www-form-urlencoded` is what github sends, making this a very misleading error message.

review_comments.body: It wasn't although it was required in order to get the project to build.  Is this suppose to be configured elsewhere on my local machine?
Yes, that could be a little bit more stable.
Being a person that has never used maven or build a jenkins plugin this took a little while to figure out, is there a reason it shouldn't be in the pom?

This is not correct.  There is a distinct difference between `git@github.com:jenkinsci/jenkins.git` and `ssh://git@github.com/jenkinsci/jenkins.git`.  It might look like they are interchangeable to you, but that is incorrect.  In fact, by default, the second one would be identical to: `ssh://git@github.com:22/jenkinsci/jenkins.git`.  Note that the SSH port number must be specified via a colon.  With your change, you are now assuming that the path to the git repository is "22/jenkinsci/jenkins.git", and that is wrong.

Take Gerrit code review, as an example:  `ssh://jenkins@gerrit.company.com:29418/jenkinsci/jenkins.git`.  This is the proper format of an `ssh://` URL.  Your change makes that incompatible.
Yep, you're correct. I wasn't paying attention closely enough.
`cause` is not used
Thanks for the comment!  I've made the change locally and am testing in our build environment.  I'll update this pull-request shortly.

Interestingly enough, I've been seeing some threads lock up the CPUs since making this change.  The stacktraces i see in the monitor are identical to those in the bug @ https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-14362.

If it's not caught soon enough, the memory get's sucked up and swapping starts to occur.  When i manually kill the threads, the resources are released.

Although i did only upgrade from 1.515 to 1.516, I think you are correct in saying it's not likely related.  I read some of the other comments in the bug and realized that some links i was sending out in emails used the ConsoleFull instead of Console.  Since changing that, i have not seen the exception, but i'll keep my eyes on it.

When i have more time, likely after tomorrow, i'll see if i can change it back in order to reproduce the problem.  If reproducible, i'll attempt to install your jenkins build w/ the proposed fix.

Having a look at this PR to see if it could help with a problem we're having.

Are you sure that `ref` always points to `ref/heads/`? AFAIK if you push tags to GitHub then `ref` could refer to `refs/tags/`. An actual event we see can look like:

``` json
{
  "ref": "refs/tags/[TAG]",
  "after": "[SAH1]",
  "before": "0000000000000000000000000000000000000000",
  "created": true,
  "deleted": false,
  "forced": true,
  "compare": "https://github.com/[ORG]/[REPO]/compare/[TAG]",
  "commits": [],
 ...
```

Or am I misunderstanding where `ref` comes from?

I think we do want tags - I can see cases were it is useful anyway.

I'm making the required change now.

Looking at this further, it looks like we don't need to deal with tags specifically, because the sha1 matches the tag. Instead we should restrict the branches to ref/heads. This PR looks like it would do bad things with anything that didnt match ref/heads.
